bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 23, 1875

div1.p: Reed pledges to abstain from irony in his future correspondence with Emilie Lawrence.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 23, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
Sept. 23rd, 75.

div1.p:
Several
times, to-day, I have asked
myself whether I was awake
or dreaming, and, each
time, concluded that I must
be dreaming. I was sitting
quietly in my room, this
morning, leisurely turning
over the leaves of a
favorite author, when
suddenly my door-bell
sounded, and in came
an “Orderly” with a letter.
I examined the hand-writing
on the enveloped, & then the
envelope itself, both of
which seemed familiar-
“but still the wonder grew”-
I then opened it & read
“Oakland, Septr 19th,”- Said
I, “it must be, and yet, can it
be possible”? I began to
read- The sentences were
smooth & well-turned-
a little farther on, when
suddenly “zip-” an arrows
flies- Thinks I, “can I
be mistaken”? I had scarce-
ly uttered the words when, “whiz,”
another flies by me, and
another & another- “Ah,” said
I, “none other than my little
“B.,” and on turning to the
last page, there was your
own dear signature! To be
sure, I may consider, and
do consider, myself as being
highly honored. Accept my
profoundest bow! Continue
the good work, so well be-
gun! It may be a little irk-
some at first, but you
will soon get used to it,
and then I shall be made
so happy! And you thought
of a cold & stormy night of
last september? Ah! well
do I remember it! Poor,
sick boy, his heart going “pit a
pat-”; his tongue paralized!-
And there sat the angel
whom he worshiped -- cold,
formal, calm-! what did
she he care for him!
Nothing! A friend? scarcely-
An acquaintance? Yes, and noth-
ing more- Well, times do change.
Then, it was “Miss Lawrence”-
but now -- Oh! glorious now --
it is, “my own precious Em-
ilie”! And can it be that
our hearts have been thus
drawn together, only to be
torn apart in the Future?
Let those who have no trust
in humanity, & who look
always on the dark side,
say “yes”- but I will not,
I cannot believe it! I know
that there is much happiness
in store for us, if we will
only seek it- and knowing
this, I shall faithfully act
my part; trusting that Heav-
en may smile upon us & that,
each day, our hearts may be
brought into a closer, sweeter
communion-

I was a little but surprised
at your reference to my
style of writing- Have you
“sheathed your swords”? If
so, my perception must be
dull, as I had not observed
it- Think again, & you will, I
think, see your mistake- At
least, I have a few letters,
of recent date, that contain
much that is “ironical-” Still
it is only playful & innocent,
& I so understood it- and
desired & thought that the
same construction should
be put on mine. Neverthe-
less, I will not be surpas-
sed in obedience, & from
this time forth shall ab-
stain from all ironical
indulgences; provided you
will do likewise- There is one
sentence in your last letter,
my darling, which I beg that
you will change- In fact,
your language is too vigorous
altogether- You say that I
alluded to Miss Bettie Reed
in a “disrespectful” manner --
That I do not like- inasmuch
as I am not accustomed to speak
“disrespectfully” of ladies- Re-
ally, my darling Emilie, you
forget that a person's in-
tentions may be quite dif-
ferent from the construction
which others may put
upon them. I am not seek-
ing to apologize for any
expressions which I may
have used toward the
said young lady,- on the
other ,hand, I am willing to be held
responsible for all my words-
I can call her Miss “Betsy
Jane,” without being “dis-
respectful”- I am not trying to lec-
ture you, my little B. but Ias
wish to remove a false
impression from your mind-
an impression which has
lead you to judge me more
severely than you should,
and which, if not removed,
should rightly lower me
in your estimation. When
I next see you, I will allude
to this, more at length. I
had a long letter from Ma,
to-day- You know that she
had been quite sick, I
presume- she said that she
had neglected to answer
your letter, but would write
soon- She is a dear, good
mother, & thinks that you are
the greatest girl in America-
and she is quite right-!
She wanted to know if I wrote
to you very often, & whether
you answered all my letters.
Just think of that! As if she
had never been young & as
if my illustrious father did
not write to her, at least,
twice a day! of course, I'll have
to tell her that you do an-
swer them all, since you have
done so very recently- Present
my kindest regards to Mrs. Frank,
and tell her, that I shall en-
deavour to comply with her wish-
es by coming to M.'boro, very soon-
Remember me, also, to Mrs. Harold
& your mother-

closer.salute:
Believe me, darling,
As ever, your fond & devoted
closer.seg:
P.S. Do not, at once, say that I am
sensitive; but rather attribute
my plain speech to a jealous
desire to allude to any noone,
(lady or gentleman) in other
language than such as
would merit your entire
approbation-
yrs. W.R.
